I’ve always found that the internet to be my continuing humanities and social sciences education with a very enthusiastic and intelligent class of grad students. it’s gotten worse in recent years

i joined john schulman’s RL team (he hadnt yet invented the term posttraining) roughly the week chatgpt launched. ilya gave a resounding speech that im sure half the people in the room still remember, as he does, about not letting external validation get to us (mixed success there) and that AGI is coming and nobody is yet prepared for dealing with it, successful product or no

we watched this grow from barely working locally to everyone i see in every country I visit has it as their homepage, several people on this flight are using it even now: in many ways accessible intelligence too cheap to meter happened. nearly a billion people now talk to this single entity weekly, reaching a scale only other tech giants and maybe three major religions achieve. it’s surpassed many hurdles of intelligence, scaled tremendously. even our free products now are superior (in some ways) to the paid model in 2023. few will remember that making models do math or reliably browse the web then was just really not working

it’s been the honor of my life watching it up close, making my small contribution, and hopefully documenting one angle of its story

some of my favorite times at the old openai building was just finding Alec in the cafeteria and trying to get him interested in whatever research topic I cared about (generally model creativity) - this always worked fantastically. old OpenAI had the feeling of a legendary university library where you could just knock on the door of modern day Einstein’s and Feynman’s and get them interested in your problems, and discuss all the great open questions of machine learning with them

dude American companies are full of American white people, why would they not be? Look at the executive suite of any of these companies! 

But the tech industry employs today like *four times* the number of people it did in the year 2000, some of whom are of indian or asian descent. Due to the sheer numbers you’d have to believe you’d get some serious contingent of talented people come from those populations. 

All I want is for the modern right, like the more capitalist right before it, to admit that these folks have made a contribution to this country, not some insane thing about their superiority or inferiority. I love white people and I love America

I disagree with what I said in January. I was very defensive then due to the initial spate of racial attacks and I’ve learned more about H1B since. I’ll write something about this. Here in print: I do not care for cognizant and their visa-backed business model. Americans shouldn’t have to compete with them. Of course labor is global, and certain services can be done anywhere. But they shouldn’t have to compete with tax advantaged low end visa labor on american soil
